title: How to Tie a Tie: The Four-in-Hand Knot
description: Learn to tie the classic and versatile Four-in-Hand knot, a simple and popular choice for any occasion. This step-by-step guide will have you looking sharp in minutes.

steps.title: Drape the Tie
steps.description: Stand in front of a mirror wearing a collared shirt with the top button fastened and the collar popped up. Drape the tie around your neck, over the collar. The wide end of the tie should be on your right side, and the narrow end on your left. Adjust the tie so the wide end hangs about 12 inches (30 cm) lower than the narrow end. The seam of the tie should be facing your shirt.
tips: For most people, the tip of the narrow end should be roughly at the level of your navel to start.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph of a person standing in front of a mirror. They are wearing a crisp, light blue collared shirt with the collar up. A classic navy blue silk tie is draped around their neck. The wide end on the right hangs significantly lower (about 12 inches) than the narrow end on the left. The lighting is bright and even, highlighting the texture of the tie and shirt. The focus is sharp on the tie and collar area. The background is a simple, neutral-colored wall.

steps.title: Cross the Wide End Over
steps.description: Take the wide end of the tie in your right hand and cross it over the narrow end, moving it from right to left. The wide end should now be on your left side.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph from the same perspective. The person's hands are visible, gently guiding the wide end of the navy blue tie over the top of the narrow end. The wide end is moving from the right side to the left. The narrow end is held steady with the left hand against the chest. The lighting remains bright and even. The focus is on the point where the two ends of the tie cross.

steps.title: Bring the Wide End Under
steps.description: Now, bring the wide end underneath the narrow end, moving it from left to right. The wide end should now be back on your right side, with its seam facing outwards.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph. The person's right hand is guiding the wide end of the tie underneath the narrow end, moving from left to right. The seam of the wide end is now visible. The left hand continues to hold the narrow end in place. Bright, even lighting. The focus is on the knot beginning to form at the collar.

steps.title: Cross Over the Front Again
steps.description: Bring the wide end back over the front of the narrow end one more time, moving from right to left. You are essentially wrapping the front of the knot you are forming.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph. The wide end of the tie is being brought across the front of the knot again, from right to left. This creates a horizontal band across the front of the developing knot. The person's hands are clearly shown performing the action. Consistent bright, even lighting. The focus is on the front of the knot.

steps.title: Up Through the Neck Loop
steps.description: Bring the tip of the wide end up through the loop that has formed between your collar and the tie. Pull it all the way through so it points towards the ceiling.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph. The person is using their right hand to feed the tip of the wide end of the tie up through the space between the tie and the shirt collar. The wide end is pointing upwards. The focus is sharp on the tip of the tie emerging from the top of the neck loop. Consistent bright, even lighting.

steps.title: Down Through the Front Knot
steps.description: You have now created a small horizontal loop on the front of the knot with the last crossover. Carefully feed the tip of the wide end down through this front loop. Do not pull it tight yet.
tips: Use your index finger to keep the front loop slightly open, making it easier to pass the wide end through.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph. The wide end of the tie, which was pointing up, is now being threaded down through the horizontal loop on the front of the knot. The person's index finger is shown slightly holding the loop open for the tie to pass through. Consistent bright, even lighting. The focus is on the tip of the tie passing through the front loop.

steps.title: Tighten and Adjust the Knot
steps.description: Hold the narrow end of the tie with one hand and gently pull down on the wide end with the other to tighten the knot. Once it's snug, slide the entire knot up towards your collar by holding the knot with one hand and pulling on the narrow end with the other. Adjust until the knot is centered and sits comfortably against your collar.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, chest-level photograph. Both of the person's hands are visible. One hand is holding the base of the newly formed knot, while the other is gently pulling down on the wide end to tighten it. The knot is almost at the collar but not fully tightened yet. The focus is on the knot itself, showing its characteristic asymmetrical shape. Consistent bright, even lighting.

steps.title: Final Touches
steps.description: Fold your shirt collar down over the tie. Check the length: the tip of the wide end should end at or just above your belt buckle. The narrow end should be shorter and can be tucked into the keeper loop on the back of the wide end. Create a 'dimple' just below the knot by pinching the fabric before the final tightening for a polished look.
tips: If the tie is too long or too short, you'll need to untie it and start over, adjusting the initial starting position from Step 1.
steps.image_prompt: A final, polished chest-level photograph. The person's shirt collar is folded down neatly over the finished navy blue tie. The Four-in-Hand knot is snug and centered at the collar, with a subtle dimple just below it. The tip of the wide end of the tie is perfectly aligned with the top of a leather belt buckle. The lighting is bright and even, giving a professional look. The focus is on the entire finished look from the collar to the belt line.

safety_notes: Ensure the tie is not too tight around your neck. You should be able to comfortably fit two fingers between the tie and your neck. A tie that is too tight can restrict breathing and blood flow.
